data.title: Civil War Veterans Buried in Beaver Cemetery and Clark Park
data.meta_description: Showing the magnitude of how the Civil War impacted the community of Beaver, a remarkable count of 356 Civil War veterans are buried in two cemeteries in the Borough of Beaver — Clark Park (61) and Beaver Cemetery (295). All but one served with the Union Army. Col. Richard P. Roberts The list on this page […]
data.text:
Showing the magnitude of how the Civil War impacted the community of Beaver, a remarkable count of 356 Civil War veterans are buried in two cemeteries in the Borough of Beaver — Clark Park (61) and Beaver Cemetery (295). All but one served with the Union Army.

Col. Richard P. Roberts

The list on this page is provided in partnership with the Beaver Cemetery & Mausoleum, based on an original compilation by Marcia Weil of Freedom, Pennsylvania.

At least four of the soldiers who rest in Clark Park — William J. Marks, Thomas Shawness, Howell Walton and Richard Walton — died in the military service of their country. Four others — among them Alfred Cairns, Frasher Dillon, Joseph F. Kennedy and Richard Naltin — died during the war years between 1862 and 1865, and may also have been casualties of the conflict.

Sgt. David W. Scott

Col. Richard P. Roberts, interred in Beaver Cemetery, was killed at the Wheat Field during the Battle of Gettysburg.

One of the soldiers who rests in Beaver Cemetery, Sgt. David W. Scott, a Brighton Township farmer, was shot in the jaw at the Battle of Gettysburg, and briefly taken prisoner. Some 200 of his wartime letters, as well as a tooth and fragment of his jawbone from his wound, are preserved today in the permanent collection of the Beaver Area Heritage Museum. Included in the “Scott Collection” is his portfolio satchel which contained personal items such as paper, a quill pen, locks of keepsake hair, wool, thread and needles to repair his clothing, a comb, and water proof bags, as well as a handkerchief signed by his fiancée Caroline Barclay. These artifacts are on display through the end of 2012 as part of the museum’s “Civil War” exhibit.
